subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... I was aware that the dictionary had multiple entries, but not that the first was the more common one. Is this always the case? If so, then I will
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Taking these one by one:
>
> 1) The CMU Dictionary has multiple entries, for example:
>
> IMPLEMENTING IH1 M P L AH0 M EH2 N T IH0 NG
> IMPLEMENTING(2) IH1 M P L AH0 M EH2 N IH0 NG
>
> The first entry is *much* more common in the US. The 'T' needs to be
> included in a standard spelling.
>
> 2) The 'H' needs to be there. Again, we should use the first entry in
> the dictionary:
>
> HUMAN HH Y UW1 M AH0 N
> HUMAN(2) Y UW1 M AH0 N
>
> 3) Such cases (rules for condensing QS spelling) can easily be handled
> programatically, but let's not get ahead of ourselves.
>

I was aware that the dictionary had multiple entries, but not that the
first was the more common one. Is this always the case? If so, then I
will re-created the dictionary, omitting all entries after the first.

Paul
